title: Exploring the Link Between Full-Fat Dairy and Reduced Dementia Risk
summary: A recent study published in Neurology in December 2025 suggests that consuming higher amounts of full-fat cheese and cream may be associated with a lower risk of developing dementia later in life. Conducted by researchers at Lund University in Sweden, the study analyzed data from 27,670 adults over approximately 25 years, starting when participants were around 58 years old. During this period, 3,208 individuals were diagnosed with dementia. The research focused on high-fat dairy products, defining high-fat cheese as having over 20% fat (e.g., cheddar, Brie) and high-fat cream as containing 30-40% fat (e.g., whipping cream). Participants recorded their food intake for a week and answered questions about long-term eating habits. Results showed that those consuming 50 grams or more of high-fat cheese daily had a 13% lower dementia risk compared to those eating less than 15 grams, with a stronger association for vascular dementia (29% lower risk). High-fat cream consumption of 20 grams or more daily was linked to a 16% lower risk. The study notes that this is an association, not proof of causation, and highlights how it challenges previous dietary guidelines that often limited high-fat foods. Factors like age, sex, education, and overall diet were adjusted for in the analysis.

background_read: Dementia is a major global health issue affecting millions, with types like Alzheimer's and vascular dementia linked to factors such as genetics, lifestyle, and diet. Historically, dietary guidelines have often recommended limiting high-fat foods due to concerns about heart disease and obesity, but recent research explores potential benefits of certain fats for brain health. Longitudinal studies, like this one from Sweden, are valuable for observing long-term effects but have limitations, such as reliance on self-reported data. Understanding associations between diet and dementia can inform public health strategies, but caution is needed to avoid misinterpretation as direct prevention.
Article_Structure: Main Points: The study found that higher consumption of full-fat cheese and cream is associated with a reduced risk of dementia, specifically 13% lower for cheese and 16% for cream, with stronger effects for vascular dementia. Purpose: To investigate the relationship between high-fat dairy intake and dementia risk, challenging previous dietary assumptions. Evidence Evaluation: The evidence comes from a large longitudinal study with 27,670 participants, using food diaries and questionnaires, but it is observational and cannot prove causation. Author Credibility: Researchers are from Lund University, with Emily Sonestedt, PhD, as a lead, suggesting expertise in nutrition and epidemiology. Methodology: Data collection involved dietary records over a week and long-term food frequency questions, with adjustments for confounders like age and diet quality.

perspectives.description: This perspective highlights how dietary fats might play a role in brain health, suggesting a shift from blanket recommendations against high-fat foods.
